title: Ex-Philadelphia Eagles CB Orlando Scandrick rips organization, former teammates
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Week 7 was good to Lorenzo's Locks. Hoping for the same luck with Week 8! USA TODAY

On Monday, the Philadelphia Eagles released cornerback Orlando Scandrick. On Friday, he made his feelings about the organization known.

Scandrick appeared on FS1’s "Undisputed" and had a lot to say about his former teammates and coaches. Notably, he claimed: "The problem in Philadelphia is much, much deeper than me. I think they’re having a tough time dealing with success.”

The 32-year-old was cut after training camp but re-signed when the Eagles experienced injury woes in September. He recorded two strip-sacks and a touchdown in Week 5 before being released again. Scandrick dubbed the move, “really, really scapegoat-ish.”

He addressed more topics than his own hardships, calling out specific individuals within the organization, and his reviews weren’t exactly glowing.

Scandrick went in on former teammates, saying the Eagles' defense was full of selfish players. But he reserved specific criticism for safety and team captain Malcolm Jenkins. The Eagles have had coverage issues all season, and Scandrick said Jenkins should step up.

Jenkins responded to Scandrick’s comments on Friday afternoon. Talking to the media, Jenkins said, “For us to move on as a team, we can’t have (expletive) like that in the room.”

Yet not all of Scandrick’s comments were scathing. He had nothing but praise for quarterback Carson Wentz, calling him “a great guy” and saying he was “stand-up.”

The Eagles had not yet responded to a message from USA TODAY Sports on Friday afternoon.

Philadelphia has struggled so far this season and is 3-4. The Eagles were blown out by the Dallas Cowboys last week in an embarrassing 37-10 loss. They will look to turn things around on Sunday against a resurgent Buffalo Bills team.
description: After being released earlier this week, ex-Eagles CB Orlando Scandrick trashed the Philly organization and former teammates in a scathing interview.
